info.name: System Design Learning - DNS, CDN, Transport, Security

request.description:
STEP 1: Basic HTTP GET request
Shows how a simple GET request works

What you'll see:
- status: healthy
- protocol: HTTP
- timestamp: current time

How it works:
1. Browser sends GET request
2. Server processes it
3. Server responds with JSON
4. Browser displays result

STEP 2: Understanding request headers
Shows all headers sent by Postman

Important headers:
- User-Agent: Which client is making request
- Accept: What format you want (JSON, HTML, etc)
- Content-Type: Format of data being sent
- Authorization: Auth tokens

Try these exercises:
1. Add custom header: x-custom: myvalue
2. Notice it shows up in response
3. Change User-Agent to something else

Get all users from the server
Method: GET (retrieve data, no body)
Response: Array of users

Get a specific user by ID
Change the '1' to different IDs to get other users
Try: /api/users/2, /api/users/999 (not found)

Create a new user
Method: POST (send data to create)
Body: JSON with name and email
Response: Created user with new ID

Try:
1. Change name and email
2. Leave out email (see error)
3. Create multiple users
4. Then GET /api/users to see all

Update an existing user
Method: PUT (modify existing data)
Change ID in URL to update different users
Body: New name/email

Delete a user
Method: DELETE (remove data)
Change ID to delete different users
After deleting, GET /api/users to confirm

STEP 6: CDN & Caching
Notice response headers:
- Cache-Control: public, max-age=3600
- This tells CDN to cache for 1 hour

Look in Response ‚Üí Headers to see:
- Cache-Control
- ETag
- X-Cache-Strategy

These headers help CDN decide what to cache

Non-cacheable content
Notice headers:
- Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate
- CDN won't cache this

Used for:
- User-specific data
- Real-time information
- Session data

STEP 3: Security - API Key validation
This request will FAIL because x-api-key is wrong
You'll get 401 Unauthorized

Response: "Invalid or missing API key"

STEP 3: Security - With correct API Key
This request will SUCCEED
x-api-key: secret123 (correct!)

You'll get 200 OK

Learning Points:
1. APIs need authentication
2. API keys authenticate the client
3. Always use HTTPS for sensitive data
4. In production, use OAuth, JWT, etc

STEP 4: HTTPS/TLS - Secure connection
Note: Port 5443 (HTTPS) instead of 5000 (HTTP)

‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT:
1. Run app-https.py first: python app-https.py
2. In Postman Settings ‚Üí General
3. Disable 'SSL certificate verification' (self-signed cert)
4. Then this will work

What changed:
- Data is now ENCRYPTED
- Connection is SECURE
- Uses TLS/SSL protocol
- Certificate validates server identity

View server's SSL/TLS certificate information
Shows:
- Certificate type
- Location on server
- Why we use certificates
- Production tips

SYSTEM DESIGN LEARNING PROJECT

üìö Complete Learning Path:

1. START WITH HTTP
   - Run: python backend/app.py
   - Open browser: http://localhost:5000
   - Test: Health Check request
   - Learn: How HTTP works

2. EXPLORE REQUEST/RESPONSE
   - Test: View Your Headers
   - Learn: Client sends headers
   - Learn: Server responds with headers
   - Learn: Cache-Control, ETag, etc

3. PRACTICE CRUD OPERATIONS
   - Create users (POST)
   - Read users (GET)
   - Update users (PUT)
   - Delete users (DELETE)

4. LEARN CACHING & CDN
   - Test cache demo
   - Look at response headers
   - Understand Cache-Control
   - See how CDN uses these headers

5. UPGRADE TO HTTPS
   - Run: python backend/app-https.py
   - Test on port 5443
   - Disable SSL verification in Postman
   - See connection is encrypted

6. UNDERSTAND DNS
   - Edit /etc/hosts on your computer
   - Add: 127.0.0.1  myapp.local
   - Test: ping myapp.local
   - Access: http://myapp.local:5000

7. OPEN FRONTEND
   - Double-click: frontend/index.html
   - Or run: python -m http.server 8000
   - Visit: http://localhost:8000
   - All tests in one UI!

üìù Key Concepts:
HTTP ‚Üí Transport protocol for web
DNS ‚Üí Maps domain names to IP addresses
CDN ‚Üí Distributes content worldwide
HTTPS ‚Üí HTTP + encryption (TLS/SSL)
TLS/SSL ‚Üí Encrypts data in transit
Cache ‚Üí Store frequently accessed data
API Key ‚Üí Authenticate API requests
ETag ‚Üí Identify content version

üéØ Testing:
- Use this Postman collection
- Try each request
- Look at Response ‚Üí Headers
- Understand what each header does
- Experiment with changes
- Learn from errors!
